newsitem.title: AUSTRALIA: Costello sees long period of growth for Australia.
newsitem.headline: Costello sees long period of growth for Australia.

text.p: Australian Treasurer Peter Costello said on Wednesday that Australia had to prepare itself for an extra long period of economic growth.
"I think that what we ought to be looking at in this country is setting ourselves up for a long economic cycle," he told a post-Budget business dinner.
"We don't want the boom and bust of the 1980s," he said.

"But if we can keep inflation low and interest rates low and address our savings problem, absent some major intervention from overseas, it could be a very long cycle that we haven't seen for quite some time in this country," he said.
Costello on Tuesday announced the Federal budget for the year to June 1998 and in doing so projected economic growth continuing until fiscal 2000/01.
If the forecasts were met, the economy will have sustained 10 unbroken years of solid economic growth.
The Australian economy historically has had difficulty sustaining growth for longer than five or six years.

Usually an expansion phase is halted by a slump in commodity prices although in 1990 Australia preceded the world slowdown, entering a deep recession that economists blamed largely on an asset-price bubble bursting.
